hello everybody my name is chris volosh and i'm the vice president of system security and chief information security
officer at election systems and software welcome to black hat and our presentation on
building a vulnerability disclosure program that works for election vendors and hackers
i am joined by mark kerr who is the chief technology officer at synac esns and synack are working
together to improve election security and you're going to hear about our partnership and relationship
with security researchers to test election technology and improve
public awareness and public trust of our elections quick information about me i used to
work at the department of health and human services in washington dc
the va a couple other jobs and then 20 plus years in the u.s navy
all positions worried about security networking and improving the security of
our infrastructure hi everybody my name is mark core i'm
the co-founder and chief technology officer at synac synack is a leader in the crowdsource security space what we do is
is recruit retain and vet a global community of security researchers and bring them on to our software platform
to find exploitable vulnerabilities in our customers applications and infrastructure prior to this i was at the national
security agency doing hands-on keyboard exploitation operations and also worked as an analyst
and what you realize doing that job is that it really matters the type of team you can bring
to bear on a problem and and really focused on the mission and this
this talk is meant to you know help improve public awareness of what we're doing to improve
the security of our election systems and as the most sacred aspect of our
democracy it's super important and i'm proud to present uh with esns on this topic on what we

interconnected and intertwined and we must take a comprehensive approach to securing our infrastructure next
slide the state of election security is
definitely improving especially in the relationship with security researchers you know if you take a look back at the early 2000s
we had the the election in florida uh in the in the 2000 presidential election where we had some
issues with hanging chats and this you know led us to move from a
physical ballot to more of an electronic method for counting and tallying our votes this
you know led to the establishment of the election assistance commission and over the years we have seen that
more electronic voting is more prevalent and you can vote online you can vote by mail using online registration and voter
registration databases it's all moving into the internet era um one of the
things that you know this this timeline is meant to show though is that this is all intertwined the evolution of
voting infrastructure and the relationship of the government uh with the security research community
is all intermingled and what we're looking at over the last 20 years but specifically in 2016 is
the federal government launches the hack the pentagon program to start working with security researchers on critical infrastructure on defense
systems you know leveraging that talent in a crowd-sourced way to find vulnerabilities that an
adversary could find but we're trying to find them in advance and if you apply this to our elections
infrastructure it's also designated as critical infrastructure by dhs
in response to russian interference in the 2018 and 2016 elections
you know so what we're seeing is you know there is a a match made in heaven here between the security research community
and the the government bodies that manage our elections infrastructure and what we're trying to do is advance
that and improve that collaboration because it can be quite valuable
um you're seeing that the security vendors are you know actually stepping up to offer

in in 2019 on election guard um synack and and cloudflare offering you know pro

is such an important issue for the general public that we must have an answer for how we're

and how we're going to integrate the vendor relationship and the researcher researchers that are out
there doing great work into a more comprehensive solution and this has led to
you know darpa getting involved and really advancing the state of the art in computer security which we're going

and then we're going to talk about the esn s partnership and what esns is doing to really improve their relationship with security
researchers overall though this is dramatically improved uh given
public pressure on on election security and uh the voting uh you know voting systems
being a primary target for our adversaries this is this is something that should not be overlooked
um and and i'm glad to see it improving now with all that in mind i'd like to touch on what
uh crowdsource security actually is there's a lot of a lot of terms floating around and i want to make sure we level
set before we jump into you know what this can actually mean in practice in general
you know the you start out with something called a vulnerability disclosure program and these are basic policies and
procedures for external security researchers to report vulnerabilities to
uh vendors uh to you know the government and and this is a see something say something equivalent
your your c an issue you report it then we evolved that model to an open bug bounty model where
researchers are compensated for their findings they're given a payment for finding and this is
allowing us to incentivize that research a little bit more but there's a there's a lot less control
and if you need a model that is very focused on specific use cases or you have sensitive systems that you're not
willing to put on the external internet you might move to the next model which is an invite-only bug bounty
which allows us to you know privately select a crowd of researchers with specific skills
and incentivize them to go after specific attack factors that are of particular interest maybe maybe things that have come up in
our threat modeling that we know the adversaries are are focused on this is primarily what
um what has been used by the by the pentagon and by other government agencies on critical infrastructure
and then this model evolves to a more comprehensive offering that that i like to call manage crowdsource
pen testing you know pen testing has pro traditionally been an approach uh
led by consultants where a consultant comes in and runs through a checklist and you know compares that checklist to
you know various compliance standards whether it's nist 853 or pci and that's great but it also
in this model also integrates open vulnerability discovery where we're able to incentivize researchers
to find vulnerabilities that are interesting and also you know exploitable then we also
integrate into this model automated scanning there's definitely a place for automated vulnerability
scanning and the integration of the open volume discovery the automated scanning and the compliance driven checklist approach is
is what makes this model quite different and more comprehensive in addition you layer in analytics and auditability and
trackability with firm controls over the rules of engagement to get the most comprehensive matrix
team approach to to your pen test thanks mark i am proud of the work the progress that

to communicate those the availability of that program and to collaborate with

they are actively working on election security issues and i'm proud to report uh that that
collaboration is working i'd also like to point out that crowdsource pen testing at the
state level is in play the state of colorado is working with synac uh to pen test to use crowdsource pen
testing specifically as a crucial part of their cyber security program i'm quoting the colorado secretary of
state chief information officer trevor timmons where synack is making
inroads and working with states specifically to improve the election security posture of
state election systems my first example is the citrix net scalar
widely advertised back in december and january of 2020 a researcher by the name of jack cable
well-known well-respected part of hack the pentagon and other important initiatives
reached out to esns to alert us to a citrix netscaler vpn
potential vulnerability with malware we worked with jack to identify the the
vulnerability the device that was involved and to ensure
that a vulnerability a patch of mitigation was in place and then test it jack was very effective
and professional in communicating with esns he was uh helped us
understand the vulnerability the seriousness of it explained uh his uh
the way that he used to uh find that vulnerability and then work with us to mitigate it
example two comes from two professional researchers kevin scoglin and tony adams kevin and tony worked for
about a year scanning the internet using a methodology that you can see on the slide here to scan
for ports 22 and 443 that with specific responses could
fingerprint firewalls that may be used by election officials in the communication of unofficial results
because without proper security controls or misconfigurations these devices could be vulnerable to
abuse by external threat actors we worked with kevin and tony who also reported these
issues to the e i i isac to customers and to dhs we worked with this group to make sure
and help our customers address this vulnerability
example three also comes from kevin scotland and tony adams they did a great job reviewing the
documentation that election technology vendors submit to the eac
in anticipation of a certification event kevin and tony reviewed this
documentation and and discovered that a certain model of a zebra qr code scanner uh out of the box
uh coming direct from the factory could have a vulnerability when using configuration barcodes these
are special manufacturer divine barcodes which can be scanned by the scanner to perform perform ad administrative
functions kevin and tony alerted us to this and working together we reviewed our
implementation of these zebra scanners to make sure that our our implementation
did not or would not be susceptible to this vulnerability and we actually used kevin's suggestion
about how to mitigate this recommendation so i i thank kevin and tony for their proactive approach to working
with technology manufacturers to ensure that we're doing everything as securely as we can be
my final example comes from a a high school kid named hunter osmera
hunter was reviewing uh voter view application websites and found that if he put random
characters into the name fields of a voter lookup uh website that he could return
uh names and voter information of voters in that jurisdiction kevin
alerted us to this uh function this vulnerability and we worked with him to make sure that special characters would
be ignored and the search parameter tightened up to make sure that only
authentic characters input into these fields would return the desired results
hunter as i mentioned a high school kid proactive professional willing to work
with the technology manufacturer to ensure that our systems are as secure as they can be
very important now but especially important as we move towards november
thank you chris as you can see there are a lot of vulnerabilities up and down the stack here from everything from from code
readers to you know voter registration systems to voter registration databases these
are very complex systems uh that are interwoven and you know to tackle such a problem is that we really
need an aggressive approach that allows us to be as comprehensive as possible and it is a united effort

going to launch secure the election initiative that is updated to include vulnerability disclosure programs
as well as a pro bono penetration test included in this package this is going
to help us push for the idea that states should be working with
that external researcher community to find these vulnerabilities ahead of the adversary and help make our elections
the most secure they can be this is not a a new initiative but it is updated to
include even more comprehensive penetration testing with a crowd of researchers and
incentivized discovery so this is a way for us to help the states move into a modern era of pen
testing and follow the lead that colorado has set by moving and making this part of their core
security platform the end result will hopefully be vulnerabilities found ahead of
our adversaries and a more secure elections infrastructure
that said i want to talk a little bit about the future where do we go to secure uh the future of our elections
infrastructure beyond just better collaboration between researchers and the vendors the defense advanced
research projects agency has been working on a very interesting project
to integrate formal methods a formal valid validation of uh pro program flow
into hardware to start to prevent vulnerabilities in software with a hardware approach
this program is is really on the cutting edge and is designed to help us eliminate whole classes of
vulnerabilities from from the average series toolkit this is especially relevant for voting
infrastructure and other critical systems as a part of this and to validate that the approach
is effective senec will be working with darpa on a bug bounty focused on this and a voter
registration database use case that allows us to validate that this approach can be used
in that type of model in these types of systems that esns builds this is meant to advance and further
harden these systems against future attacks and just like you know we'd expect from from darpa
they're way ahead of the curve here we're excited to work with them to make sure that these hardware
vulnerabilities can be implemented in a way that allows software to be
loaded on top of them and and prevent whole classes of vulnerabilities next i want to go into what those
those are this you know this darpa research has focused on eliminating things like
buffer overflows information leaks anything that that could be done you know at the programmatic level and numeric errors
code injection even cryptographic errors that lead to code execution this is going to hopefully allow us to
focus on other vulnerability classes like business logic or functional abuse that
may be abused in a fraud type scenario given our focus on on these vulnerabilities and darpa's
ability to bring a more hardware driven approach we're hoping that in time for the the 2024 elections we'll
be able to have an even more secure infrastructure for this
thanks mark as mark mentioned at the at the top of the presentation the iti
sac uh has taken a special interest in vulnerability disclosure programs and is leaning in
helped form a election industry special interest group and has brought a number of election

disclosure disclosure program which will move the industry forward towards a vdp
i'm also excited to announce that esn s is partnering with synac to test our newest generation electronic
poll book these poll books are in wide use across the country they are the perimeter or the front line
of election technology where voters enter a polling place and are checked in
using an electronic poll book we want to make sure that everything that can be done to harden and protect
these electronic poll books and their communications methodology with a central voter registration database are
as absolutely secure as they can be thanks chris we're
excited to get to work on that project as the next step i'd like to talk about
where we can go next in terms of the policies especially when it comes to the federal testing
programs you know there are certainly certainly been a lot of progress made in the last
you know five years on this we certainly have you know seen that researchers can get
involved with the vendors we've seen that researchers can get involved with the state and local governments and work
with them to make this more secure you know orchestrated voting uh election infrastructure
however there are more things we can do the testing timelines are are just too elongated we need to have
the ability to do continuous testing on these products we need to be able to push
patches to the field very quickly the continuous testing model is is being
adapted by adopted by a lot of people and critical infrastructure is a great place to start
for this type of testing because we know that it has ramifications if a vulnerability is found and we know that
changes need to be you know controlled that makes sense but we also need to be able to validate
those changes work and marry that with continuous security testing the incorporation of federal standards
on this type of product is also needed you know right now states do not have to buy
voter voter registration systems that are you know rigorously security tested there's a lot of optional requirements
and i think we can move most of the optional requirements to mandatory ones uh with with little
downside risk we ought to be able to you know push the envelope here especially on this this type of system
where we the the public demands that we deliver a more secure voting infrastructure they do not want to see adversaries
meddle with our elections and we just need we owe it to the general public to do a much better job
public awareness is rising and you know if the states and the and the vendors are more proactive
i think we'll see some very positive results from the general public
thanks mark another topic that's closely related to discovering vulnerabilities before our adversaries do
are supply chain security considerations and we want to take the last portion of our
our presentation here to talk to you about all that's going on in supply chain security and what esns is
doing to make sure that the parts that we use in our equipment are absolutely secure and trustworthy
our product life cycle begins at the design phase when we develop requirements in conjunction with
what our customers those state and local election officials are demanding in terms of security
we put that through a rigorous review we bid for the parts that are used to
develop these systems we make sure that the development and the quality assurance is absolutely
airtight using the highest federal and quality quality assurance standards
every machine that we make every every piece of software that we develop goes
through rigorous federal testing and certification and then we sustain these uh
these pieces of equipment that have generally a 10 or 15 year product life
cycle as is the case with many critical infrastructure sectors
esns has a global supply chain we work very hard to make sure that each and every part
that goes into our equipment is absolutely safe trustworthy
free of malware or manipulation to make sure that when our election technology
reaches the customers hands and voters use it they can rest assured that a all the
controls that can be in place to protect these parts and services are in fact in place and tested
some of the things that we do at esns i personally conduct a a review of our supplier partners
supply chains i have visited these sites where these components are made to
ensure that no malware is is nefariously implanted
on these device no rogue or counterfeit components i i take pictures i i review
these uh my surveys and supply chain reviews uh with our engineering and management
team to make sure number one that our suppliers are doing everything that they are contractually required to do
and two is there anything else that we can look at or or ask for that helps ensure the
security of the supply chain the audits that i do are both on-site uh
with the manufacturers teams and through surveys and reviews that we
conduct remotely and then spot check to make sure that our manufacturers
are providing pristine malware-free components
once all these parts come together in omaha we have several teams that review them
and we do something extra that i think you'll find very interesting we take a random sample of these parts
and we extract any firmware and review it against a golden standard to make sure that the firmware is not
manipulated or uh somehow uh nefariously changed to induce an
undesired result we check our programmable logic devices
to make sure that they only contain the firmware that we authorize and nothing else
i would be remiss if i didn't mention that the dhs sysa and the election task force have
produced a number of guidelines for state and local officials to
learn about and help work through supply chain management issues i invite everybody
on this presentation to take a look at what dhs sysa and the election task force have
produced when it comes to ensuring that the supply chain of the technology provided by the
vendors is absolutely trustworthy there's a lot of good information that cisa and the election task force has put
out uh in the last several months of course related to covet and managing

uh next question looks like it's from kim she asks chris how does the sns do a

uh and then they tell us they they give us reports of uh of how complete how accurate
uh have there been any changes and so far well that program has been in place about 18 months and all of the equipment
that we have checked have not had firmware uh manipulated or otherwise
otherwise changed from the golden build that that we have established hope that
answers your question
